description: From Middle English were, weren, from Old English wǣre, wǣron, wǣren, from Proto-Germanic *wēz-, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂wes-. More at was.

entries.meaning: second-person singular simple past indicative of be
examples: John, you were the only person to see him.

entries.meaning: first/second/third-person plural simple past indicative of be
examples: Mary and John, you were right.
They were to be the best of friends from that day on.

entries.meaning: first/second/third-person singular/plural simple present/past subjunctive of be
examples: I wish that it were Sunday.

I wish that I were with you.
with “if” omitted, put first in an “if” clause:
Were it simply that she wore a hat, I would not be upset at all. (= If it were simply...)
Were father a king, we would have war. (= If father were a king,...)

entries.meaning: (Northern England) first/third-person singular simple past indicative of be.

description: From Middle English were, wer, see wer.

examples: Every man was valued at a certain sum, which was called his were.

description: Back-formation from werewolf and other terms in were-, from the same source as English wer, were (“man”) (above).

entries.meaning: (fandom slang) The collective name for any kind of person that changes into another form under certain conditions, including the werewolf.
